Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Radio p-Chip for Intracellular Sensing and Communication
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims at developing a Radio p-Chip, the first microchip with a sensor that can be injected into live cells, and transmit information from within without a physical connection. The design combines elements of laser light-activation of the p-Chip, a novel device that transmits the chip's serial number via radio signals, with enhancements to monitor events by adding a sensor. The target dimensions for the Radio p-Chip are suitable for investigations of large cells. The on-board sensor will gather information about real-time physiological conditions in the cell and transmit it along with the serial number identifying the cell itself. The information will be transmitted to a reading station that will collect data related to the identity of the cell, as well as the reported conditions from the sensor. The main goals of the Phase I project are to 1) design, build and test the fully functional prototype of the Radio p-Chip; 2) implant the device into a living mammalian cell and demonstrate its function; and 3) build and test components of a future version of the chip. The device envisioned is one part of a system incorporating, in addition to the chip, a custom-designed receiver and antenna system, the stimulus apparatus, devices to implant the chip into cells, and associated firmware and application software.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be felt in a wide variety of applications, including the readout of key physiological characteristics, ID-tagging of individual cells and tracking their history, tagging embryos, flow cytometry and process monitoring. All research to date with living cells relies upon indirect or intrusive methods that almost always effect what is being measured. The Radio p-Chip will be superior in both performance and cost and will have a wide commercial impact. The development of a Radio p-Chip will provide a powerful new tool for cell biology and in particular for the in vivo studying of a wide variety of human diseases and have implications for drug discovery and in vitro diagnostics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

A radio p-Chip for intracellular sensing and communication

The main objective of this project has been to design and show the feasibility of placing a small electronic device into a living cell. The device would be capable of transmitting a serial number to identify the cell, along with the value of a sensor for a parameter such as temperature or pH. Measurements will be made in real time and sent to a receiver that will process and report the data. The device, which has been designated as the “radio p-Chip” is based on PharmaSeq’s previous p-Chip, the world’s smallest electronic tag (0.5 mm square). When illuminated with a laser, the light provides the energy to activate the p-Chip that then transmits a preprogrammed serial number to the receiver. p-Chips are fabricated in silicon foundries in a manner that is similar to computer memory or processor chips.

 

With the support of a Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) grant from the National Science Foundation, PharmaSeq is working on two significant design modifications to convert the p-Chip to the radio p-Chip. They are:  1) to change the p-Chip design to allow communication of the sensor data to the outside receiver, and 2) to fabricate a sensor on the surface that will report a change in either a chemical or physical parameter as it occurs. The successful completion of this, along with development of manipulation methods will make it possible to place radio p-Chips into a living cells and monitor changes in physiology over time (milliseconds to hours and days). During phase I of the project, PharmaSeq successfully designed a working sensor, integrated it into the p-Chip and demonstrated that a small silicon device can be implanted into living cells.

 

The eventual completion of the radio p-Chip system (chips, receivers, manipulation tools) will have a profound impact in a broad range of areas in cell biology since, for the first time, it will be possible to monitor changes inside a cell as they are exposed to outside influences. Currently this is done by measuring changes in color with dyes that have been infused into cells or using electrophysiology methods that require microscopic wires. The radio p-Chip will provide an alternative to these approaches and provide real time telemetry of changes with almost no disruption of the cell. It is projected that the quality of the data will improve and reduce many of the errors experienced with current methods. Application areas include basic research in cell biology, physiology and biochemistry as well as in applied areas such as drug discovery and advanced clinical diagnostics. The radio p-Chip will be inexpensive and very easy to use. As such, it will possible for students in both college and secondary schools perform experiments as part of their circulars in life science studies.
